abstract: Have you seen this video? Entitled Peter Schiff Was Right, 2006-2007, it is an amazing, nine-minute compilation that features Mr. Schiff, the president of Euro-Pacific Capital, suffering the slings and arrows of various market gurus like Arthur Laffer, as he bravely predicts — again and again and again — in various television appearances that the housing bubble is going to lead to economic disaster. One thing that makes it amazing is how unflinching Mr. Schiff is, how unyielding, how matter-of-fact, no matter how scornful and sneering the response from the other talking heads. Even when they laugh at him, he keeps coming back. The other thing that makes it amazing, of course, is that Mr. Schiff absolutely nailed the current crisis — and did so many, many months before the rest of us could feel the first tremor.
lead_paragraph: Have you seen this video? Entitled Peter Schiff Was Right, 2006-2007, it is an amazing, nine-minute compilation that features Mr. Schiff, the president of Euro-Pacific Capital, suffering the slings and arrows of various market gurus like Arthur Laffer, as he bravely predicts — again and again and again — in various television appearances that the housing bubble is going to lead to economic disaster. One thing that makes it amazing is how unflinching Mr. Schiff is, how unyielding, how matter-of-fact, no matter how scornful and sneering the response from the other talking heads. Even when they laugh at him, he keeps coming back. The other thing that makes it amazing, of course, is that Mr. Schiff absolutely nailed the current crisis — and did so many, many months before the rest of us could feel the first tremor.

headline.main: Peter Schiff — and Shawn Tully — Were Right

abstract: The Blue card from American Express once had a smart chip and card reader for home use. Now it makes you eligible for an old-fashioned day planner.
snippet: The Blue card from American Express once had a smart chip and card reader for home use. Now it makes you eligible for an old-fashioned day planner.
lead_paragraph: Back when it was introduced in 1999, the Blue card from American Express was marketed as the first credit card specifically meant to be used on the Internet. It came with a microprocessor chip embedded in the plastic, as well as a smart-card reader that people could plug into their computers for making secure Internet transactions. Not too many people had heard of smart-card readers back then, but a lot of people did like the card’s futuristic look — translucent plastic — and the fact that it charged no annual fee.

abstract: The German auto parts and weapons supplier will eliminate 750 jobs because of slowing automotive demand.
snippet: The German auto parts and weapons supplier will eliminate 750 jobs because of slowing automotive demand.
lead_paragraph: Rheinmetall, the German auto parts and weapons supplier, will eliminate 750 jobs, reduce fixed costs by 50 million euros ($63.8 million) and extend Christmas production breaks because of slowing automotive demand. Rheinmetall will accelerate restructuring at German factories, leading to 250 job losses by early 2010 on top of the 500 temporary workers let go over the past two months, the company said. Expenses will be lowered by reducing energy, maintenance and information technology spending, a spokesman, Peter Rücker, said. The manufacturer’s automotive plants will extend the Christmas break to as long as four weeks and nearly all German workers will have reduced working hours in the first half of 2009, the company said. Automotive capital spending will be trimmed “significantly” next year and Rheinmetall said it is considering other measures. Rheinmetall is based in Düsseldorf.

headline.main: Rheinmetall Announces Job Cuts
headline.print_headline: Rheinmetall Announces Job Cuts

abstract: Taiwan’s inflation rate cooled for a fourth month, giving the central bank more room to ease borrowing costs to bolster the nation’s slowing economy.
snippet: Taiwan’s inflation rate cooled for a fourth month, giving the central bank more room to ease borrowing costs to bolster the nation’s slowing economy.
lead_paragraph: Taiwan’s inflation rate cooled for a fourth month, giving the central bank more room to ease borrowing costs to bolster the nation’s slowing economy. Consumer prices climbed 1.88 percent in November from a year earlier after increasing 2.39 percent in October, the state statistics bureau said. The government forecasts the nation will fall into a recession this year after shrinking in the third quarter for the first time since 2003. Slowing inflation makes it more likely the central bank will cut interest rates at a meeting on Dec. 11, the fifth reduction since September. “We expect the central bank to cut 25 basis points” to 2.5 percent next week, Tony Phoo, an economist at Standard Chartered Bank in Taipei, said before the report was released. “Policy makers are expected to join the government’s efforts to stimulate growth.”

headline.main: Inflation Eases in Taiwan, Signaling a Rate Cut

That limited its appeal, as corporate users in particular tend to shy away from using software that is still in test mode. Perhaps as a result, Chrome’s share of the Web browser market  is less than 1 percent. In the new browser wars, that’s a rounding error compared with Internet Explorer’s nearly 70 percent market share.

lead_paragraph: The International Paper Company, one of the world’s largest makers of office paper and corrugated packaging, plans to cut its global work force by 1,000 to 1,500 employees by the end of next year. The company, based in Memphis, said the cuts would help reduce costs $150 million to $200 million. It also plans to save $400 million from its $6 billion purchase of the Weyerhaeuser Company’s recycling and corrugated-packaging businesses in August. The job reductions were announced in a regulatory filing, which was released after the close of regular trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

abstract: The Sovereign Bancorp, a savings and loan that agreed to be acquired by Spanish Banco Santander, is cutting 1,000 jobs beginning immediately.
snippet: The Sovereign Bancorp, a savings and loan that agreed to be acquired by Spanish Banco Santander, is cutting 1,000 jobs beginning immediately.
lead_paragraph: The Sovereign Bancorp, a savings and loan that agreed to be acquired by Spanish Banco Santander, is cutting 1,000 jobs beginning immediately. The cuts, to continue throughout 2009, will “take place across the company,” Sovereign said. The cuts will affect about 8.3 percent of the lender’s 12,000 employees, and some have already been notified, a spokeswoman, Ellen Molle said. Sovereign, based in Philadelphia, was forced to sell itself to Santander after customers withdrew $4.2 billion, or 9 percent, in deposits in the weeks leading up to the United States government’s $700 billion bank bailout.

abstract: Dassault Aviation agreed to buy Alcatel-Lucent’s 20.78 percent stake in Thales, a maker of flight electronics, for about 1.57 billion euros ($2.24 billion).
snippet: Dassault Aviation agreed to buy Alcatel-Lucent’s 20.78 percent stake in Thales, a maker of flight electronics, for about 1.57 billion euros ($2.24 billion).
lead_paragraph: Dassault Aviation agreed to buy Alcatel-Lucent’s 20.78 percent stake in Thales, a maker of flight electronics, for about 1.57 billion euros ($2.24 billion). Dassault, maker of the Rafale fighter and Falcon corporate jets, will pay 38 euros a share (about $55). Dassault already owns 5.2 percent of Thales and the expanded holding will make it a close second to the French state, which owns 27.1 percent. Together they’ll control 61 percent of the voting rights.

abstract: In Mumbai, the talk is about America and its headlong rush into the subprime lending, and the disaster that ensued.
snippet: In Mumbai, the talk is about America and its headlong rush into the subprime lending, and the disaster that ensued.
lead_paragraph: I went to Mumbai this week, thinking I would learn about how India is dealing with the credit crisis. Truth to tell, the country is dealing with the aftermath of its own real-estate and stock-market bubbles — not to mention the terrorist attacks that took place in late November — but those reports will have to wait for future columns. What I quickly discovered is that most people wanted to talk about America and its headlong rush into subprime lending, and the disaster that ensued. “We used to think that America was the teacher and we were the students,” one businessman told me over breakfast this morning. “We always thought you knew so much more than us. That notion has been shattered.”

headline.main: The View From India

You can see the most popular models, explore different brands, read user reviews and see samples of photos taken with a specific camera. Contracts investigated by the authority could “limit access to the French electricity market and may lead to an abuse of its dominant position,” the company said in a statement. The company said the questioning “in no way prejudges” a final decision taken by the European Commission, the executive body of the European Union.

abstract: The Sanlu Group, the Chinese dairy company closed in September after it sold contaminated infant formula, has been declared bankrupt by a Chinese court.
snippet: The Sanlu Group, the Chinese dairy company closed in September after it sold contaminated infant formula, has been declared bankrupt by a Chinese court.
lead_paragraph: The Sanlu Group, the Chinese dairy company closed in September after it sold contaminated infant formula, has been declared bankrupt by a Chinese court, its partner, the Fonterra Cooperative Group of New Zealand, said. A receiver will take over management of the company and has six months to sell its assets and pay creditors, Fonterra said in a statement. At least six infants died and more than 54,000 were hospitalized after 22 companies including Sanlu sold formula made from milk contaminated with melamine, an industrial chemical. Fonterra has 43 percent of a venture with Sanlu and has written off its 200 million New Zealand dollars ($115 million) investment.

headline.main: Infant Formula Company Is Declared Bankrupt
headline.print_headline: Infant Formula Company Is Declared Bankrupt

Some of the plants are owned by Tyson Foods and process poultry, pork and beef, a report on the department’s Web site showed. Smithfield Foods also owns facilities on the list of plants that cannot ship some meats to Mexico.

abstract: The maker of the wrinkle smoother Botox, won federal approval to sell the first prescription medicine to make eyelashes longer, darker and thicker.
snippet: The maker of the wrinkle smoother Botox, won federal approval to sell the first prescription medicine to make eyelashes longer, darker and thicker.
lead_paragraph: Allergan, maker of the wrinkle smoother Botox, won federal approval to sell the first prescription medicine to make eyelashes longer, darker and thicker. The Food and Drug Administration cleared the drug, Latisse, to treat hypotrichosis of the eyelashes, or a deficiency of the lashes, Allergan said. Latisse contains the same main ingredient as the company’s Lumigan, on the market for glaucoma since 2001. The drug will be introduced in the United States before the end of March, Allergan said.

headline.main: Allergan Eyelash Treatment Approved
headline.print_headline: Allergan Eyelash Treatment Approved

abstract: Russia’s gas-export monopoly said that Ukraine was unconstructive in talks over a debt dispute that could lead to the second cutoff of fuel shipments in three years.
snippet: Russia’s gas-export monopoly said that Ukraine was unconstructive in talks over a debt dispute that could lead to the second cutoff of fuel shipments in three years.
lead_paragraph: Gazprom, Russia’s gas-export monopoly, said that Ukraine was unconstructive in talks over a debt dispute that could lead to the second cutoff of fuel shipments in three years. “In such a situation there will be no legal grounds” to deliver gas to Ukraine as of Thursday, Gazprom’s chief executive, Alexei Miller, said in a letter. Gazprom, which supplies a quarter of Europe’s gas, mainly through Ukraine’s pipeline system, refuses to sign a new delivery contract with Ukraine until it pays off a debt of more than $2 billion.

headline.main: Gazprom Threatens Gas Cutoff Over Debt
headline.print_headline: Gazprom Threatens Gas Cutoff Over Debt

abstract: Ukraine’s current-account deficit widened to 6.7 percent of its gross domestic product in the first 11 months of the year.
snippet: Ukraine’s current-account deficit widened to 6.7 percent of its gross domestic product in the first 11 months of the year.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s current-account deficit widened to 6.7 percent of its gross domestic product in the first 11 months of the year as exports, especially steel and chemicals, slowed amid turmoil in world markets. The current-account gap totaled $11.7 billion, the central bank said. The monthly deficit totaled $1.6 billion. Ukraine’s steel exports dropped 49.4 percent in November from the previous month; chemical exports declined 34.1 percent and grain exports decreased 18.9 percent, the bank said. The state’s trade deficit widened to $15.3 billion, compared with $8.9 billion in the same period a year ago, the central bank said.

headline.main: Ukraine’s Trade Gap Widens
headline.print_headline: Ukraine’s Trade Gap Widens

snippet: A little delegation from a major investment bank said a money manager of stupendous acumen never lost money.
lead_paragraph: ABOUT two years ago, a little delegation from a major investment bank arrived at my home in Beverly Hills. These nice young people were from the bank’s “wealth management division.” I told them straight away that I didn’t have anywhere near enough wealth to make their trip worth their time, but they smilingly insisted that we could help each other.

headline.main: They Told Me That Madoff Never Lost Money
headline.print_headline: They Told Me He Never Lost Money

abstract: The public assumes that wireless carriers’ costs are far higher than they actually are, and profit margins are concealed by a heavy curtain.

abstract: Russia devalued the ruble for the third time in a week, sending the currency to its lowest level against the dollar since January 2006 as the price of a barrel of crude oil dropped  below $36  dimmed the outlook for growth. The Russian central bank allowed the ruble to fall about 1 percent against a basket of dollars and euros, accelerating the slide after spending $162.7 billion trying to defend the currency over four months. The government needs crude oil to average $70 a barrel to balance its budget. The currency has fallen 14 percent against the dollar this year as the price of a barrel of oil has fallen 75 percent since its high in July of $145.29 a barrel. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

abstract: South Korea posted a current-account surplus for a second consecutive month in November, which may help ease pressure on the won.
snippet: South Korea posted a current-account surplus for a second consecutive month in November, which may help ease pressure on the won.
lead_paragraph: South Korea posted a current-account surplus for a second consecutive month in November, which may help ease pressure on the won, the region’s worst-performing currency this year. The surplus was $2.06 billion, compared with $1.67 billion in November 2007, the Bank of Korea said. The current account is the broadest measure of trade, tracking goods, services and investment income. The nation posted a record $4.75 billion excess in October. A surplus means there are more dollars flowing into the country than those going out, bolstering the supply of United States dollars in the local currency market and strengthening the won’s value. South Korea has posted current-account shortfalls every month but three this year as higher oil prices and the weaker won drove up the cost of imported goods.

headline.main: South Korea: A Second Consecutive Trade Surplus
headline.print_headline: SOUTH KOREA: A SECOND CONSECUTIVE TRADE SURPLUS

abstract: France’s economy expanded in the third quarter as a drop in oil prices helped consumer spending. Gross domestic product rose 0.1 percent from the second quarter.
snippet: France’s economy expanded in the third quarter as a drop in oil prices helped consumer spending. Gross domestic product rose 0.1 percent from the second quarter.
lead_paragraph: France’s economy expanded in the third quarter as a drop in oil prices helped consumer spending. Gross domestic product in the country rose 0.1 percent from the second quarter, when it shrank 0.3 percent, the national statistics office, Insee, said. The figures are unchanged from a Nov. 14 estimate. Consumer spending rose 0.2 percent in the third quarter after stagnating in the second quarter. Households saved 15.4 percent of their disposable income, the lowest rate in two years. Exports and imports rose 1.4 percent and 1.7 percent, respectively, after falling the previous quarter.

headline.main: France: Economy Expands as Oil Price Falls
headline.print_headline: France: Economy Expands as Oil Price Falls

abstract: Hong Kong’s exports fell for the first time in five months in November, worsening the outlook for an economy already in recession.
snippet: Hong Kong’s exports fell for the first time in five months in November, worsening the outlook for an economy already in recession.
lead_paragraph: Hong Kong’s exports fell for the first time in five months in November, worsening the outlook for an economy already in recession. Overseas sales declined 5.3 percent from a year earlier, to 231 billion Hong Kong dollars ($29.8 billion), the government said, after gaining 9.4 percent in October. Asia’s export-dependent economies are being battered by falling demand for electronics and textiles. Imports fell 7.9 percent, to 239 billion Hong Kong dollars, leaving a trade deficit of 8.2 billion Hong Kong dollars.

headline.main: Hong Kong: Exports Decline 5.3%
headline.print_headline: HONG KONG: EXPORTS DECLINE 5.3%

abstract: Media moguls have had a rough year, but John Malone appears to have salvaged some value for his shareholders at the expense of another mogul’s shareholders.

lead_paragraph: Media moguls have had a rough year. Sumner Redstone is jettisoning assets to maintain control of Viacom and CBS. Despite a breakup, Barry Diller’s empire of Internet assets has plunged in value. Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation has lost about $30 billion of market cap. Yet amid the rubble, one mogul, John Malone, appears to have salvaged some semblance of value for his shareholders at the expense of another mogul’s shareholders.

headline.main: Liberty Media’s Boss, a Hero to His Shareholders
headline.print_headline: A Media Mogul Who Stands Out; Sold Too Soon

snippet: Different countries at different time periods respond differently to the same economic stimulus program, posing a problem for economists looking to the past for answers about how to solve today’s crisis.
lead_paragraph: We’ve been keeping track of various proposals for a fiscal stimulus package, which is now reportedly in the $675 billion to $775 billion range. The International Monetary Fund today released its own list of recommendations for an internationally coordinated stimulus plan. It suggests, among other things, a more aggressive economic stimulus package in the United States than in Europe because Europe already has “relatively large automatic stabilizers.”

headline.main: Even More Stimulus Proposals: Advice From the I.M.F.

abstract: The headline on a front-page article on Friday, on the role in the housing bubble and consumption binge in the United States played by investment from China, could have been misunderstood. The article described how the United States has been tolerating a huge trade deficit with China while Chinese authorities have invested huge sums in American government securities from savings partly created by the inflow of American dollars. “Dollar Shift: Chinese Pockets Filled as Americans’ Emptied” meant to describe the complications of that situation; it did not mean to imply that China has profited from the weakness of the American economy.

abstract: The challenges of getting the new Yahoo Mail out the door are emblematic of the company’s struggles in 2008.
snippet: The challenges of getting the new Yahoo Mail out the door are emblematic of the company’s struggles in 2008.
lead_paragraph: It’s no secret that this has been a tough year for Yahoo. For investors, the company’s two major setbacks were the failed merger negotiations with Microsoft and the failed advertising partnership with Google, which disintegrated in the face of opposition from advertisers and the Justice Department. For many employees, much of the pain came from two rounds of layoffs, seemingly endless rounds of reorganizations and a sense that they were riding on a rudderless ship.

headline.main: A Tough Year for Yahoo

snippet: Bank Medici, a small Viennese merchant bank, lost billions of dollars it invested with Bernard L. Madoff.
lead_paragraph: Austria’s financial regulator is considering appointing an outside overseer to the board of Bank Medici, the small Viennese merchant bank that lost billions of dollars it invested with Bernard L. Madoff, the American fund manager who has confessed to running a multibillion-dollar international fraud, a person with knowledge of the government’s discussions said Wednesday.

abstract: Innergie has created a charger, the mCube90, that lets you charge many models of notebook computers as well as any other device that can be charged through a U.S.B. port.
snippet: Innergie has created a charger, the mCube90, that lets you charge many models of notebook computers as well as any other device that can be charged through a U.S.B. port.
lead_paragraph: Most gadgets do not play well together. This exclusivity means using separate chargers for each device, which makes traveling light difficult. Innergie, a maker of power adapters, has created a charger, the mCube90, that lets you charge many models of notebook computers  including models from Acer, Asus, Compaq, Dell, Lenovo and Sony  as well as any other device, like an Apple iPod, that can be charged through a U.S.B. port.

headline.main: When Laptops and iPhones Need a Kick in the Battery, One Charger Can Feed All

abstract: It’s a little-known fact that cellphone carriers will let you swap contracts with another person, no matter whether you have one month or two years remaining on your commitment.
snippet: It’s a little-known fact that cellphone carriers will let you swap contracts with another person, no matter whether you have one month or two years remaining on your commitment.
lead_paragraph: The last of the major wireless carriers recently made it cheaper to escape your contract by pro-rating early termination fees. But if you bought that new BlackBerry Storm last month, only to find you would rather have something else, you still face contract cancellation fees of up to $175.

headline.main: With a Little Help, You Can Trade Yourself Free of Your Wireless Contract
headline.print_headline: With a Little Help, You Can Trade Yourself Free of Your Wireless Contract

abstract: Facebook allows its members to tinker with amount of status updates they see from a particular pal in their News Feed.
snippet: Facebook allows its members to tinker with amount of status updates they see from a particular pal in their News Feed.
lead_paragraph: The News Feed feature on Facebook, which displays recent status updates, comments and posted photos, is a great way to see what your friends have been up to lately. But some friends may be a little more active and dominate the feed, crowding out acquaintances who post less, or who are not as close to you. Facebook allows its members to tinker with the mix. On the News Feed page, hover over a friend’s name or update with the cursor until an Options link appears on the right side of the line. Click on the link to get the choice to see fewer (or even more) updates from this particular pal. For more ways to fiddle with the feed, click on the Options for News Feed link at the bottom of the page.

headline.main: Tip of the Week: Seeing Less of Your Friends on Facebook
